pyopticontrol.CSDAESolver module

class pyopticontrol.CSDAESolver.OCPCASADI(ocp, ode_sol, alg_sol)[source]

Bases: object

This class links a TPBVP written in the Casadi framework into the NumPy framework to be solved using the BVPDAE class.

Parameters:

  • ocp – OCP written in the Casadi framework, returning the right-hand side of the ODEs, the algebraic equations, and the boundary conditions.

  • ode_sol – NumPy array containing the ODEs’ solution.

  • alg_sol – NumPy array containing the solution of the algebraic equations.

algeq(time, ode_sol, alg_sol)[source]

This function returns the residual of the algbreaic equations

Parameters:

  • time – Numpy array of time steps at discretization points

  • ode_sol – 2d Numpy array of ODEs’solution at discretization points

  • alg_sol – 2d Numpy array of algebraic variables at discretization points

Returns:

res_alg_eq: 2d Numpy array of residual of algebraic equations

algjac(time, ode_sol, alg_sol)[source]

This function returns the Jacobians of the algebraix equations as three dimensional Numpy arrays

Parameters:

  • time – Numpy array of discretization time steps

  • ode_sol – Numpy array of ODEs’ solution at discretization points

  • alg_sol – Numpy array of algebraic solutions at discretization points

Returns:

  • jac_alg_wrt_ode_sol: 3D Numpy array of algebraic equations Jacobian with respect to ode_sol at discretization points

  • jac_alg_wrt_alg_sol: 3D Numpy array of algebraic equations Jacobian with respect to alg_sol at discretization points

bcjac(ode_sol_0, ode_sol_T, alg_sol_0, alg_sol_T)[source]
ode(time, ode_sol, alg_sol)[source]

This function returns the ODEs’ right hand side in NumPy array format

Parameters:

  • time – Numpy array of discretization time steps

  • ode_sol – Numpy array of ODEs’ solution at discretization points

  • alg_sol – Numpy array of algebraic solutions at discretization points

Returns:

rhs_ode: Numpy array of time derivative of ode_sol at discretization points

odejac(time, ode_sol, alg_sol)[source]

This function returns the Jacobians of the ODEs’ right-hand side as three dimensional Numpy arrays :param time: Numpy array of discretization time steps :param ode_sol: Numpy array of ODEs’ solution at discretization points :param alg_sol: Numpy array of algebraic solutions at discretization points :return:

  • jac_ode_wrt_ode_sol: 3D Numpy array of ODE’s right hand side Jacobian with respect to ode_sol at discretization points

  • jac_ode_wrt_ode_sol: 3D Numpy array of ODE’s right hand side Jacobian with respect to alg_sol at discretization points

pyopticontrol.DAESolver module

class pyopticontrol.DAESolver.BVPDAE(**kwargs)[source]

Bases: object

This is a Two Point Boundary Value Problem solver consisting in ODEs coupled with DAEs. The parameterization of the solver is done through an options dictionnary given at instanciation containing the following items
  • display:

    Verbosity of the algorithm (ranging from 0 to 2). Default is 0

  • check_jacobian

    Boolean when True checks provided Jacobian. Default is False

  • exact_prb:

    Boolean when True algebraic variables are computed exactly at collocation points. If False, alg_sol_mid is interpolated.

  • control_odes_error:

    Boolean when True time mesh is adapted to control residual error. Default is False

  • max_mesh_point:

    Maximum length of time array. Default is 1e5

  • res_tol:

    residual relative error on ODEs. Default is 1e-3

  • no_mesh_reduction:

    Boolean when True mesh modification can only add points., Default is False

  • threshold_mesh_reduction:

    Real value in (0,1] such that mesh points are removed if ODE’s residual error is <= threshold_mesh_reduction * res_tol on three consecutive time interval.

  • max_NLSE_iter:

    Maximum number of iteration for solving the NLSE. Default is 100 in case of mesh refinement 500 otherwise

  • max_rms_control_iter:

    Maximum number of mesh modification iterations. Default is 1000

  • newton_tol:

    relative tolerance of Newton scheme. Default is 1e-8

  • abs_tol:

    residual absolute error on ODEs. Default is 1e-7

  • coeff_damping:

    Damping coefficient of damping Newton-Raphson scheme. Default is 2.

  • linear_solver:

    Linear solver to be chosen among lu or umfpack. Default is umfpack

  • newton_tol:

    relative tolerance of Newton scheme. Default is 1e-6

  • coeff_damping:

    Damping coefficient of damping Newton scheme. Default is 2.

  • max_probes:

    Maximum number of damping operations for armijo step selection. Default is 6

solve(time, ode_sol, alg_sol, alg_sol_mid, ocp)[source]

Solve the Optimal Control Problem from OCP initializing the algorithm with (time, ode_sol, alg_sol) values

Parameters:

  • time – 1d-array containing time steps at discretization points

  • ode_sol – 2d-array containing the solutions of ODEs at discretization points

  • alg_sol – 2d-array containing the solutions of AEs at discretization points

  • alg_sol_mid – : 2d-array containing the solutions of AEs at collocation points (mid-interval)

  • ocp – Object representing an indirect optimal control problem

Returns:

OptiSol , Infos.

pyopticontrol.DirectSolver module

class pyopticontrol.DirectSolver.DirectSolver(**options)[source]

Bases: object

Parameters:

options –

options of the solver listed as follows:

  • display: values must be {0, 1, 2, 3} describing verbosity of the display, 0 being no display and 3 being full. Default is 0

  • print: Boolean value authorizing printing iterations of casadi solveur. Default is False

  • method : Discretization method, euler, rk4 or hermite_simpson. Default is hermite_simpson

get_solution()[source]

This method returns the numerical solution of the optimal control problem as follows

Returns:

time, x, u, [opti_parameters]

opti(OCP, opti_parameters=None)[source]

This methods builds a casadi optimization problem corresponding to the OCP provided in parameter OCP

Parameters:

  • OCP – Object instanciation of optimal control problem.

  • opti_parameters – Optional additional optimization parameters

solve()[source]

This method solves the problem using IPOPT and returns the solution of OCP as follows

Returns:

optimal solution of the problem (time, x, u, done) if opti_parameters is None (time, x, u, opti_para, done) otherwise

update_solutions(time, x, u, opti_parameters=None)[source]

This methods initialize the optimization variables to the values given as parameters

Parameters:

  • time – numpy array containing the time steps of the OCP

  • x – numpy array containing the state solution of the OCP

  • u – numpy array containing the control solution of the OCP

  • opti_parameters – iterable of float containing additional optimization parameters

abstract initialize() → tuple[ndarray, ndarray, ndarray][source]

class pyopticontrol.OptiControl.OptiControl(ocp: OCP, options=None, opti_parameters=None)[source]

Bases: object

Parameters:

  • ocp – Object instanciation describing an optimal control problem

  • options – dictionnary containing the options parametererization of the solver.

  • opti_parameters – If OCP is a direct optimization problem, one can add some additional real valued optimization parameters to the optimal control problem

solve(sol: OptiSol, opti_parameters=None) → tuple[OptiSol, Infos | Infos][source]

Solve the optimal control problem OCP provided at instanciation of class EMSOpti. If no input parameters are provided, this method calls the initialize() method of OCP problem.

Parameters:

  • sol –

    object with attributes :time:numpy array containing optimization time stamps :ode_sol: numpy array containing the initial solution of OCP.ode() at time stamps provided in time :z : numpy array containing:

    • the initial control variable if OCP is a direct optimization problem

    • the initial solution of OCP.algeq() is if OCP is an indirect optimization problem

  • opti_parameters – Optional optimization parameters. Only availabe if OCP is a direct optimization problem

Returns:

Optimal solutions of the problem:

  • time: numpy array containing optimization time stamps

  • ode_sol: numpy array containing the optimal solution of OCP.ode() at time stamps from time

  • z: numpy array containing:

    • the optimal control variable if OCP is a direct optimization problem

    • the optimal solution of OCP.algeq() is if OCP is an indirect optimization problem

  • done: informations on the optimization procedure

pyopticontrol.UtilFunctions.max_smooth(x, y, mu=1e-06, d1=0, d2=0)[source]

This functions returns the mu-smooth maximum of (x, y, dx=0, dy=0). If x and y are 1d-arrays, the function returns a 1d-array z s.t. z[i] = max_smooth(x[i], y[i])

Parameters:

  • x – NumPy array

  • y – NumPy array

  • mu – regularisation parameter of |.| ~ sqrt(. ** 2 + mu)

  • d1 – order of x-derivative of max_smooth

  • d2 – order of y-derivative of max_smooth

Returns:

(d/dx) ** d1 * (d/dy) ** d2 * (x + y + sqrt((x-y) ** 2 + mu))

pyopticontrol.UtilFunctions.min_smooth(x, y, mu=1e-06, d1=0, d2=0)[source]

This functions returns the mu-smooth maximum of (x, y, dx=0, dy=0). If x and y are 1d-arrays, the function returns a 1d-array z s.t. z[i] = max_smooth(x[i], y[i])

Parameters:

  • x – NumPy array

  • y – NumPy array

  • mu – regularisation parameter of |.| ~ sqrt(. ** 2 + mu)

  • d1 – order of x-derivative of max_smooth

  • d2 – order of y-derivative of max_smooth

Returns:

(d/dx) ** d1 * (d/dy) ** d2 * (x + y - sqrt((x-y) ** 2 + mu))

pyopticontrol.UtilFunctions.repmat(a, rep_dim)[source]

This function allows to replicated a 2D-matrix A along first, second and optionally third dimension. :param a: Matrix to be replicated :param rep_dim: tuple of integer (d0, d1, [d2]) giving the number of times matrix a is replicated along each dimension :return: NumPy array of replicated a matrix

pyopticontrol.approximate_nlse_funs module

class pyopticontrol.approximate_nlse_funs.NLSEInfos(success, iter, ode_residual, ode_tol, ae_residual, ae_tol, bc_residual, bc_tol)[source]

Bases: object

The NLSEInfos class contains the information of the DAE’s solving and has the following attributes :param success: Boolean indicating if the problems is successfully solved :param iter: number of Newton iterations :param ode_residual: Residual error on for the discretization of the ODEs :param ode_tol: Error tolerance (mesh dependent) of the ODEs :param ae_residual: Residual error for the Algebraic Equations :param ae_tol: Error tolerance of the AEs :param bc_residual: Residual error for the boundary conditions :param bc_tol: Error tolerance for the BCs

Module contents

pyopticontrol is a package for solving Optimal Control Problems (OCPs). The solving methodology is automatically derived from the structure of the optimal control problem given as a parameter when instanciating a EMSOpti object.

  • Instructions for OCP structure
    • Direct Optimization using casadi :
      In this case the input parameter OCP must embed the following methods :
      • Required methods :

        • initialize() -> return (time, x, u) initial solution of OCP

        • ode(time, x, u, [opti_parameters]) -> returns the time derivative of vector x

        • running_cost(time, x, u, [opti_parameters]) -> returns the time derivative of the cost to minimized

        • twobc(x0, xT, u0, uT, [opti_parameters]) -> returns the boundary conditions of the OCP

      • Optional methods

        • const_ineq(time, x, u, [opti_parameters]) -> returns c(time, x, u, [opti_parameters]) st c <= 0.

        • const_eq(time, x, u, [opti_parameters]) -> returns c(time, x, u, [opti_parameters]) st c == 0.

        • terminal_cost(xT) -> returns the terminal cost part of the objective function as a function of the state at final time

    • Indirect Optimization using casadi :
      In this situation the input parameter OCP must embed the following methods :

      • initialize() -> returns (time, ode_sol, u) initial solution of OCP

      • ode(t, x, z): -> returns a casadi vector of the size of x containing the value of the derivative of x

      • algeq(t, x, z): -> returns a casadi vector of the size of z containing the algebraic equations.

      • twobc(x0, xT, z0, zT): -> returns a casadi vector of the boundary conditions.

    • Indirect Optimization with NumPy Jacobian :
      In this situation the input parameter OCP must embed the following methods :

      • initialize() -> returns (time, ode_sol, u) initial solution of OCP

      • ode(t, x, z): -> returns an array of the size of x containing the value of the derivative of x at each time stamp

      • algeq(t, x, z): -> returns an array of the size of z containing the algebraic equations at each time stamp. The solution of the problem corresponds to finding z such that the algebraic equations are 0.

      • twobc(x0, xT, z0, zT): -> returns the boundary conditions. The solution of the problem consists in finding the boundary values such that twobc is 0.

      • odejac(time, x, z): -> returns (Jx, Jz) two 3D arrays such that :

        • Jx: NumPy array of size (x.shape[0], x.shape[0], len(time)). Jx[:, :, i] contains the Jacobian of the ODEs with respect to x at time t[i]

        • Jz: NumPy array of size (x.shape[0], z.shape[0], len(time)). Jz[:, :, i] contains the Jacobian of the ODEs with respect to z at time t[i]

      • algjac(time, x, z): -> returns (Gx, Gz) two 3D arrays such that:

        • Gx: NumPy array of size (z.shape[0], x.shape[0], len(time)). Gx[:, :, i] contains the Jacobian of the Algebraic Equations with respect to x at time t[i]

        • Gz: NumPy array of size (z.shape[0], z.shape[0], len(time)). Gz[:, :, i] contains the Jacobian of the Algebraic Equations with respect to z at time t[i]

      • bcjac(x0, xT, z0, zT): -> returns four arrays containing the Jacobians of the boundary conditions as follows

        • BCx0: Array of size (x0.shape[0], x0.shape[0]) contains the Jacobian of the boundary conditions with respect to x0

        • BCxT: Array of size (xT.shape[0], xT.shape[0]) contains the Jacobian of the boundary conditions with respect to xT

        • BCz0: Array of size (x0.shape[0], z0.shape[0]) contains the Jacobian of the boundary conditions with respect to z0

        • BCzT: Array of size (x0.shape[0], zT.shape[0]) contains the Jacobian of the boundary conditions with respect to zT
